hawaiian_text: I ia wā, noke aku ana ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka  huhuki ā pau kekahi māla ‘uala ā luna o kekahi  māla ‘uala, pēlā nō ka huhuki ‘ana ā pau nā māla  ‘elua ā kū ke āhua o ka lau o ka ‘uala, he kanahā  āhua ka nui o nā māla ‘elua. A laila, ho‘i a‘ela ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o a hō‘ā i ke ahi a ‘ōhinu akula ‘ehā  ‘au o ka ‘uala i luna o kapuahi e ‘ā ana. Iā ia e  ‘ōhinu ana i luna o ke ahi, ho‘i maila kona makua  kāne kōlea ā hiki, nīnau akula i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī: “‘A‘ole.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “‘Ae, ‘o ke po‘o  ona a me nā maka ka mea e ‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala i  kēia lā, no laila, eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u.”
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_t: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o tore apart one sweet potato patch completely and went up to another sweet potato patch. Thus he destroyed both patches until the sweet potato vine mounds stood erect—there were forty mounds in total from the two patches. Then Nāmakaokapāo‘o returned and kindled a fire, roasting four sweet potato vines atop the open flame. While he was roasting them atop the fire, his stepfather, Puali‘i, arrived and reached [the house], questioning his mother Pōka‘ī: “No answer?” Puali‘i asserted, “Yes, his head and eyes are the relish to flavor my sweet potatoes today, so this will be the day I kill him.”
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_c: **Paragraph 6:** • This passage contains rich allegory and numerical symbolism tied to the 'Ai Kapu era and proto-historical societal transitions: – **Numerical Symbolism:** – The destruction of *2 patches* (ʻeluaʻ) echoes dualistic themes in Hawaiian cosmology (day/night, male/female, kapu/ʻaikāpō), suggesting conflict between traditional and emerging values. – The *40 mounds* (ʻkanahāʻ) of sweet potato shoots may reflect the pauku concept—a completed cycle or generation—potentially critiquing the cyclical nature of kapu enforced labor. – *4 vines* (ʻehāʻ) roasted mirrors the four major kapuna (Hāloa, Hina, Kanaloa, Kūkailimoku) or the four main islands, symbolizing how traditional subsistence practices sustained hierarchical structures. • **Etymological & Cultural Analysis:** – Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo (“the eyes of the pāoʻo fish”): The pāoʻo (a starfish or club?) links to poʻo (head), as both are central to sustenance rituals (e.g., pāoʻo kani—conch trumpet used in ceremonies). His destructive act of tearing sweet potato mounds may symbolically dismantle the sacred agrarian hierarchy. – Pualiʻi (“child of the chief”): His name reflects the matrilineal inheritance tensions of the 'Ai Kapu era. By threatening to consume his stepchild, he enacts violent patriarchal control over lineage legitimacy. – The threatened consumption of “poʻo and maka” (head and eyes) mirrors ʻai kapu restrictions, where only high chiefs consumed the ulua fish’s head. Here, Pualiʻi perverts this custom, substituting Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s body parts for the sacred food, critiquing ritualized cannibalism as a tool of oppression. – The roasted ʻuala (sweet potato) represents the kānakaʻs lifeline—destroying patches and consuming vines symbolizes rejection of the aikāpō (sacred farming cycle), while roasting vines (rather than tubers) implies disrespect for ʻuala’s dual role as both sustenance and deified ancestor (Ka-ʻōhiʻo-ʻuala). • **Cultural Practices in Action:** – The destruction of sweet potato mounds parallels the demolition of heiau post-Kamehameha II's abolishment of the 'Ai Kapu. Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s actions foreshadow systemic rejection of oppressive traditions tied to agrarian dominance. – Pualiʻi’s threat to “eat” the child evokes pre-Christian kānaka loaʻa (long-life rituals), where destroying a disobedient youth’s spirit ensured agricultural abundance. This underscores the sacrificial rhetoric inherent to kapu enforcement. – The stepfather’s accusation that Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s head/eyes are the “relish” (ili) for sweet potatoes inverts ʻo kū lāʻau practices: typically, root vegetables were seasonally blessed before harvest; here, the kāne invokes violent consumption of human flesh to maintain control. • The symbolism points to a philosophical clash: – Nāmakaokapāoʻo embodies moʻo kāne (defiant male rebel archetypes) resisting oppressive systems. His manipulation of agricultural symbols (tearing patches, roasting vines) critiques the theft of laborer agency by ali‘i. – Pualiʻi’s response reflects a doomsday theology—if the sacred bond between people and land is severed, both the land and its people must perish. This mirrors historical violence during kapu violations, where communal survival hinged on ritual purity.

reference_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o was busy tearing  apart the sweet potato patches, yanking them out.  He tore apart both sweet potato patches until  there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves, forty  mounds in all from the two patches. Then  Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire to broil  four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was  broiling the vines, wilting them, his stepfather  came back and reached him and asked   Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s mother, Pōka‘ī, and she said,  “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes, his head and eyes as food  to go with the sweet potatoes that I’ll eat today.  So, today I will kill him.”
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 6:**• The numbers referred to in this paragraph are  interesting and likely a riddle to solve, with esoteric  meaning: 2, 4, 40\. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is a child, but  behaves like a mature adult, albeit destructive and  spiteful, but calculating. This has allegorical meaning  and likely relates to wastefulness and the need to  dismantle ‘Ai Kapu practices.  • Pua-li‘i was so enraged by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s  destruction of the sweet potato patches that he  threatened to eat his head (po‘o) and eyes (nā maka)  with sweet potato in place of ulua fish. The head of  the ulua or of a person likely represents the sweet  potato tuber and the eyes likely represent the sweet  potato vine cutting (maka) that is used to replant and  perpetuate the crop, symbolically, the people of the  land. This also explains the meaning of ʻmaka’ in the  name, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, with ʻpāo‘o’ being used  as a poetic reference to ʻpo‘o’ (head).  – Ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice  on the heiau in the ‘Ai Kapu culture (footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua*: “This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available , probably because of word magic and the meaning of *ulua 2* \[to grow/increase; to be possessed by a god\]. Since an *ulua* replaces a man, *ulua* also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs.”). In this case,  Pua-li‘i threatens to eat the human head and eyes  of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o in place of the ulua: the  opposite of normal ‘Ai Kapu custom. This appears  to allude to Pua-li‘i’s holding on to the ‘Ai Kapu  customs, going back in time allegorically, rather  than forward in time, where humans are no longer  sacrificed in the Western culture. Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o, on the other hand, represents going forward in time, a time of progressive thinking and   abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu;
